document.docAuthor: Girgan, Chantelle, Marais, Mariette, Fourie, Hendrika, Tiedt, Lourens & Swart, Antoinette
document.docTitle: Makatinus africanus Girgan & Marais & Fourie & Tiedt & Swart 2019, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: Description of two new species, Aphanolaimus strilliae n. sp. (Nematoda: Aphanolaimidae) and Makatinus africanus n. sp. (Nematoda: Aporcelaimidae), and SEM observations on three known species from freshwater sources in the Telperion Nature Reserve (Mpumalanga, South Africa)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Description of two new species, Aphanolaimus strilliae n. sp. (Nematoda: Aphanolaimidae) and Makatinus africanus n. sp. (Nematoda: Aporcelaimidae), and SEM observations on three known species from freshwater sources in the Telperion Nature Reserve (Mpumalanga, South Africa)

paragraph.tableNote:
TABLE 3. Morphometrics of
Makatinus africanus
n. sp.
females found in freshwater substrates in the Telperion Nature Reserve. All measurements in the form: mean Â± standard deviation (range).

tr.th: Lateral chord as percentage of corresponding body width
Cuticle width at dorsal side of tail
Ventral pores (from anterior to end of spear)

tableNote.paragraph: a Only measured in one specimen.
b Value same for all specimens.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description: Female (n = 6): Habitus strongly curved ventrally. Body 3228â4128 Î¼m long and moderately thick (a = 30â39). Cuticle 6â7 Î¼m thick in oesophageal region, 7â11 Î¼m at midâbody and 9â11 Î¼m on dorsal side of tail. Cuticle consisting of two distinct layers, a thin outer layer and a thicker inner layer with prominent radial lines that end as fine punctations on the outer surface. Lateral chord 15â20 Î¼m wide, occupying about 15â20% of the corresponding body width at mid-body. Three dorsal and three ventral pores always present at level of odontostylet. The dorsal pores (6â8 pores) are always restricted to the oesophageal region, whereas the ventral pores (24â33 pores) are distributed over the entire body, with 12â16 in oesophageal region. Lateral pores abundant and distributed over entire body, four at level of spear and 12â16 in oesophageal region. Lateral pores over rest of body difficult to distinguish, less distinct due to musculature of body and presence of lateral chord. Lips amalgamated, lip region set off by slight constriction, 6â10 Î¼m high and 27â29 Î¼m wide. Amphid stirrup shaped, aperture 11â14 Î¼m wide, occupying less than half corresponding body width. Odontostylet strong, 31â34 Î¼m long (measured medially from apex to base of dorsal side) and odontophore 52â65 Î¼m long. Odontostyle aperture occupies 60â70% of the total odontostyle length. Guide ring simple, situated 12â18 Î¼m from anterior end. Oesophagus muscular, 747â882 Î¼m long, gradually expanding in posterior half, basal expansion more muscular, 51â61 Î¼m wide at its widest point. Oesophageal gland nuclei obscure due to muscular basal expansion. Nerve ring not observed. Cardia 32â37 Î¼m long, tongue-like expansion at base of oesophagus. Genital tract didelphic-amphidelpic with both branches equal in length. Vulva situated at 47â52 % of the total body length. Vagina more than half the corresponding body width, consisting of 4â6 Î¼m long pars distalis vaginae , 12â18 Î¼m pars refringens vaginae and 37â57 Î¼m pars proximalis vaginae. Pars refringens vaginae consists of two large sclerotized pieces. Uterine eggs observed in most females, measuring 118â124 Î¼m long and 62â65 Î¼m wide. Ovijector muscular and distinct. Uterus long and complex in structure consisting of two oval structures containing sclerotized structures / spines. First oval structure located at junction of ovijector and uterus, second structure smaller, located just before pars dilatata uteri . Pars dilatata oviductus distinct with few sperm cells. Oviduct distinct, ovaries reflexed, typical of dorylaimids. Oocytes arranged in single row except in growth zone. Length of pre-rectum 113â167 Î¼m, that of rectum 63â76 Î¼m. Tail short, 30â43 Î¼m long, with digitate extension, 4â7 Î¼m long. Two caudal pores present.

Diagnosis and relationships:
Makatinus africanus
n. sp.
is characterised by a large body (3228â4128 Î¼m long, a = 30â39 wide), slightly set off lip region with amalgamated lips; 31â34 Î¼m long odontostyle; long tongue-shaped cardia, and stout, short tail (30â43 Î¼m long) with a small peg / digitate extension. Male absent.

FIGURE 7.
Makatinus africanus
n. sp.
female A) Anterior region with oesophagus; B) Anterior region with spear and position of amphid; C) Tail region; D) Habitus; E) Vulval region with pars distalis vaginae ( pdv ), pars refringens vaginae ( prv ) and pars proximalis vaginae ( ppv ); F) Reproductive system.

FIGURE 8. Light microscope photos of
Makatinus africanus
n. sp.
female A) Anterior region arrows indicate dorsal median pores; B) Vulval region with pars distalis vaginae ( pdv ), pars refringens vaginae ( prv ) and pars proximalis vaginae ( ppv ); C) Tail region with arrow indicating peg.

subSubSection.paragraph:
According to the latest compendium of the genus
Makatinus ( PeÃ±a-Santiago & Varela 2017 )
there are eight valid species. The descriptions of the type females of these species were compared to
Makatinus africanus
n. sp.
and the following differences were observed. Based on the presence of a digitate structure on the tail, the closest related species to
Makatinus africanus
n. sp.
is
M. punctatus Heyns, 1965
.
Makatinus africanus
n. sp.
differs from
M. punctatus
in the longer body (3228â4128 Î¼m vs 2400â3200 Î¼m); longer odontostyle ( 31â34 Âµm vs 25â27 Âµm ) and medial position of vulva (V = 47â52 % vs 56â59 %) ( Heyns 1965 ). In large body length
M. africanus
n. sp.
is also close to
M. capensis Heyns, 1965
, and
M. crassiformis ( Kreis, 1924 ) AndrÃ¡ssy, 1986
. The new species can however be distinguished from
M. capensis
in the longer odontostyle (31â34 Î¼m vs 24â28 Î¼m), less ventral pores (24â33 vs 48â50) and digitate structure on the tail tip (absent in
M. capensis
) ( Heyns 1965 ). The new species can be distinguished from the type females of
M. crassiformis
in the higher a-value or thinner body (29.6â39.3 vs 21â27); higher b-value (4.2â4.9 vs 3.6â4.3) and long tail with digitate extension (30â43 Î¼m vs 26 Î¼m without digitate extension) ( AndrÃ¡ssy 1986 ; PeÃ±a-Santiago & Varela 2017 ). The following, remaining species differ from
Makatinus africanus
n. sp.
in having a body shorter than 2700 Î¼m; an odontostyle shorter than 28 Î¼m and the absence of a digitate struc- ture on the tail:
M. aquaticus JimÃ©nez-Guirado, 1994
(L=1920â2260 Î¼m, odontostyle 22â26 Î¼m long) (PeÃ±a-San- tiago & Varela 2017);
M. heynsi Ahmad & Ahmad, 1992
(L=1960â2420 Î¼m in length, 21â25 Î¼m long odontostyle) ( Ahmad & Ahmad 1992 );
M. minor ( Loos, 1945 ) Ahmad, 1997
(L=1900â2200 Î¼m, 21â28 Î¼m long odontostyle)( Ahmad 1997 , PeÃ±a-Santiago & Varela 2017 );
M. silvaticus Ahmad, Sturhan & Wouts, 2003
(L=2350â2720 Î¼m, 25â28 Î¼m long odontostyle) (
Ahmad et al . 2003
).
Makatinus africanus
n. sp.
could not be compared to
M. goodeyi JimÃ©nez-Guirado, 1994
as the latter species is described from males only. However, based on the male body length (2200 Î¼m in
M. goodeyi
) and the length of its odontostyle (22 Î¼m in
M. goodeyi
) it is unlikely that the females found in the Telperion Nature Reserve belongs to the males of
M. goodeyi ( PeÃ±a-Santiago & Varela 2017 )
.

paragraph.materialsCitation: Type material: Holotype female on slide 50559 and paratypes ( 5 females ) on slides 50558â50559 deposited in the National Collection of Nematodes (ARCâPlant Health and Protection, Biosystematics Division, Pretoria).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality: Specimens were found in sediment and water samples collected at the Waterhole 2 site ( Table 1 ). It is located next to road 11_ 26 in the Blaauwpoort 1 section of the reserve and in high rainfall seasons water flows downstream from the Wilge River and collects in this site. Locality number MP00127 in the National Collection of Nematodes (ARCâPlant Health and Protection, Biosystematics Division, Pretoria)
.

Etymology:
Makatinus africanus
n. sp.
is named after the continent of origin.
